h3. Problem Definition

Reviews might become large and reach the file revision limit of 800, blocking users from working on it. 

Even though the {{crucible.review.content.size.limit}} [JVM System Property|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/jvm-system-properties-960155689.html] can be set in order to increase that limit, doing that might result in  slowing the instance down, and customers surely want to avoid that.

h3. Suggested Solution
It should be possible to clone reviews, as this would allow users to remove some files from the original review and to remove other files from the cloned review, and afterwards to add  more versions of remaining files to the original review and to the cloned review.

h3. Workaround
There are no known workarounds.
fields.summary: Be able to clone reviews

fields.description:
Request for enhancement to implement database checks which do not currently exist. From PS ticket:
{quote}While Crucible does warn that the save and migrate will override target database, we don't check for existing or non-clean database. Crucible will simply drop and override the target database with data from your existing database.

That means if your source and target were the same, your database was in an ouroboros situation - consuming itself by overwriting its own data.
{quote}
Basically, the app should stop (or throw a warning you have to accept) if there is not a clean database pointed to as the destination.

 

Related: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-5389
fields.summary: Database checks before overwriting

h3. Problem Definition
When creating a review via web interface and uploading a pre-commit patch, the patch file retains it's name in the review which is very helpful as it helps indicating what the patch file name relates to.

However when using the [command line|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/creating-reviews-from-the-command-line-335479612.html] or the [REST API|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#d1e542], the patch file name is generated automatically by Fisheye as something like: "CR-123-patch-1.txt"

!image-2018-10-24-13-37-53-075.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Suggested Solution
The command line script and the REST API endpoint should have a new parameter that allows specifying a patch name.

h3. Workaround
Currently the only workaround is to run database queries for changing the patch name. Follow these steps:
# Stop Crucible
# Create a database backup
# Run these SQL queries, adjusting the placeholders accordingly:
{code:sql|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
update cru_fr_detail set cru_value = '<new_patch_name>.txt' where cru_value = '<old_patch_name>.txt';

update cru_upload_item 
set    cru_description = '<new_patch_name>.txt', 
       cru_original_name = '<new_patch_name>.txt' 
where  cru_description = '<old_patch_name>.txt'' 
or     cru_original_name = '<old_patch_name>.txt'';
{code}
# Start Crucible
# Refresh the review, and the new patch name should be displayed:
!image-2018-10-24-13-50-09-404.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Allow specifying a patch name when creating reviews via REST API or Crucible.py

At the moment, Crucible(and Fisheye) use a mouse hover action to display the absolute dates of various activities, overlaid on a relative day/time (such as *Today*, *5 years ago* , *2min*).

Since the absolute date is available, we should offer the option of using the absolute date as opposed to the relative date (at any instance where the mouse hove-over is implemented, to capture all cases)

h3. Problem Definition
Currently it is only possible to archive reviews one by one by either closing or abandoning each review, but the projects themselves will remain active.

Customers might have large instances with thousands of projects. While most of them have reviews actively being worked on, some of them will never make it to fruition, but have valid, important data that our customers would like to retain.

h3. Suggested Solution
There should be a project-level archive method.

h3. Workaround
There are no workarounds thus far.


{panel:title=We are gathering feedback}
We would love to collect your feedback about project archiving in Crucible. What does the archived project mean to you? Things to consider:
 * is archived project visible on the project list?
 * is archived project visible in search?
 * are reviews from an archived project visible in search?
 * shall 'archive project' action automatically archive all reviews in it as well?
 * do you expect to reduce crucible project index reduced when a project is archived (i.e. delete obsolete data and index?)

Fee free to share your thoughts and expectations in comments.
{panel}
fields.summary: Allow archiving whole projects

Current situation

 

We have Perforce repository with a lot of streams (because each feature developed in separate stream) and when we want to review stream changes we need to create new FishEye repository for specific stream and then create review for this stream.

What problem we have with this approach - creation of new FishEye repository - it takes time to create new one, because for our repository it takes ~2 hours to index it before we can start to use it.

 

What workaround we tried

Create FishEye repository for whole Perforce repository (\\repository) instead of single stream (\\repository\stream). This doesn't work well because:
 # if you try to index it it will never succeed due to insane amount of data to index due to large number of streams
 # if you don't index it, review doesn't show changes properly for files, that were changed and reviewed stream but created before - Crucible doesn't show changes in those files

 

How it could be improved? I think you could find good solution for this based on your knowledge of FishEye/Crucible codebase, but I think if you can fix handling of changes in case 2 from above - it will be enough.

fields.description:
My team is utilizing the functionality to mark comments as "Unresolved" and "Resolved"

We however handle marking a comment as resolved in two different ways

For Team A:
 * Reviewer creates comment and marks as Unresolved
 * Author makes code change and marks comment as Resolved
 * Reviewer verifies the change and adds a +1 if he/she agrees with it being resolved

 

For Team B:
 * Reviewer creates comment and marks as Unresolved.
 * Author makes code change and responds with a  comment that the change has been made
 * Reviewer verifies the change and marks the original comment as resolved if he/she agrees with the change.

I am trying to get a consistent process for both teams, but one team feels like it shouldn't be resolved until the change is verified by the reviewer and the other team feels like it should be resolved when the author makes the change.

 

Based on this documentation [https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/crucible-4-2-release-notes-847744868.html]

I would assume that Team A is using the Unresolved/Resolved the way it was intended to be used.

 

Would it possible to enhance the comment statuses to have Unresolved, Resolved, and Verified?

So the workflow would be 
 * Reviewer creates comment and marks as Unresolved.
 * Author makes code change and marks comment as resolved.
 * Reviewer verifies the change and marks as verified he/she agrees with it being resolved.

The reason behind the "Verified" (same as a +1 for Team A) is that the reviewers are on several code reviews and they need to a way to know which changes they have verified and which they haven't (since the changes aren't all made at one time and the reviewers check the reviews they are on each morning and verify the changes that have been made).

 Records should contain information that establishes what type of event occurred, when the event occurred, source of the event, outcomes, identity of the individual.

Viewing the audit log should be restricted to administrators only.
fields.summary: Audit of privileged functions

fields.description:
We have two approaches to our review workflows.  Some people will "complete" a review to indicate that they are finished reviewing all items, even if there are unresolved comments; others will only complete a review when all issues have been resolved.  (I am one of the latter.)

To help manage my reviews, two items in the review dashboards would help direct my work.
 * Review Progress: for all reviews in my Inbox, knowing my percentage reviewed would allow me to quickly spot reviews for which new content has been added.  We get a lot of activity in Crucible and there are many reviews opened; using e-mail notification is not efficient.  I would prefer to open up Crucible and see, for example, that 4 of the 12 reviews have new content for me.
 * Unresolved Comments: similarly, knowing the number of unresolved comments for each review in both the Inbox Dashboard and Outbox Dashboard would help direct where follow up / action is required.  E.g., "29 comments (4 unresolved, 2 unread)".  To get around this, I will occasionally leave an unresolved comment unread so that I can see it on the dashboard; however, this only works for comments raised by others, not by me.

FYI, "Age" is less important to me; ideally, I would be able to configure which columns are visible in the dashboard from a short list to help manage the available screen real estate.  Although, I realize that is separate request.
fields.summary: Expand details displayed in review dashboards

All versions of Fisheye and Crucible before 4.4.3 (the fixed version for 4.4.x) and from 4.5.0 before 4.5.1 (the fixed version for 4.5.x) are affected by this vulnerability.

 * All versions of Fisheye and Crucible before 4.4.3 (the fixed version for 4.4.x) and from 4.5.0 before 4.5.1 (the fixed version for 4.5.x) are affected by this vulnerability. 


*Fix:*
 * Fisheye version 4.5.1 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download].

while configuring new projects on our crucible server it occurred to me that setting up permission schemes is rather cumbersome at the moment.

 Best regards
 
 Leonard

Review authors may not easily understand where to find the reviews that are currently pending.

This is the current workflow:
1) Author -> Create review
2) Author -> Add reviewers
3) Author -> Start review (review goes into "Outbox ->Out For Review" for the Creator, and into "Inbox To Review" for Reviewers)
...
10) Reviewers -> Complete review (review goes into "Outbox ->Completed" for reviewers, and into "Inbox ->Ready to Close" for the Creator)

Some options to address that:
- Document how to access the "Out For Review" reviews (e.g. on the [Browsing all reviews|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/browsing-all-reviews-298977476.html]) page
- Provide guidance in FishEye/Crucible itself for the authors to easily locate the reviews

Currently there are only two states for a comment or defect that requires resolution: Unresolved or Resolved. This does not allow the flexibility of a reviewer reporting an issue, an author indicating they have fixed the issue, and the reviewer confirming that the issue has been resolved.

Adding a new "Verify" action with a "Verified" state after "Resolved" would be extremely beneficial for the workflow of managing comments and defects. It would allow a reviewer the ability to ignore all previously verified comments and defects, instead of having to dig through all resolved comments and defects to find the ones most recently resolved. It also allows the author a logical way of keeping track of which comments and defects they have already addressed without impeding the reviewers workflow. It should also be possible to take a comment or defect from "Verified" back to "Unresolved" state in the event that the author re-introduces a previously addressed issue.
fields.summary: Add "Verify" Step to Comment/Defect Resolution
